title: How to Bake White Fish

steps.headline: Sprinkle the fish with fresh herbs for a Mediterranean dish.
steps.description: This quick recipe adds rich flavors to any white fish while in reality is very light and butter-free. Pour 1 ½ tbsp lemon juice and 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) extra virgin olive oil, rub 2 cloves of garlic (crushed and minced), and sprinkle 1 tsp fresh thyme, sea salt, pepper, and paprika as per your preference all over your fish. Although this recipe gives justice to any white fish, it is ideal for cod. When sprinkling the herbs on the fish, divide them equally along its surface. For whole fish, you can make three diagonal small cuts into the side of the fish, so that the flavors also get into the flesh.

steps.headline: Make a sour cream topping for a mildly tart flavor.
steps.description: If you want to elevate the flavors of white fish, go for a simple yet powerful dill sour cream topping. In a bowl add ¾ cup of sour cream, ½ tsp salt, ½ tsp ground black pepper, ½ tsp lemon zest, 1 tsp fresh dill, 3 cloves of garlic, 3 green onions, ½ tsp red pepper flakes, lemon juice from ½ lemon, and ⅓ cup of grated parmesan cheese.Mix the ingredients together and set aside the bowl. To balance the different flavors in your plate, serve with a simple side dish of fresh vegetables such as green beans, or with orzo, rice, or pasta.

steps.headline: Turn the Caesar salad dressing into a topping for juicy fish.
steps.description: This unusual topping is very friendly to most types of white fish, as it keeps the meat moist and tender. In a small bowl add 3 tsp fresh lemon juice, ¼ cup mayonnaise, 4 mashed anchovy fillets or 1 ½ anchovy paste, 1 clove of garlic (minced), 1 tsp Dijon mustard, ½ tsp Worcestershire sauce, salt, black pepper, and paprika. Whisk the mixture until is creamy. Then, add ½ cup of freshly grated parmesan cheese. Be cautious when seasoning with salt, as the anchovies are already salty. It is advisable to rinse and pat the anchovy fillets dry before mashing. However, for convenience and practicality, you can use anchovy paste.

steps.headline: Use crumbs for a crunchy topping.
steps.description: Children are especially keen on this recipe, as it reminisces the classic fish fingers. In a pan heat 1 tablespoon (14.8 ml) olive oil and sauté 1 diced onion and 1 clove of garlic (minced). Add 6 tablespoon (88.7 ml) of breadcrumbs and stir for 2 minutes. Remove the pan from the heat and stir in 1 ½ tsp of fresh minced thyme or dill, 3 tablespoon (44.4 ml) of fresh minced parsley, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Try this recipe especially with frozen fish fillets. You can play around with the quantity of breadcrumbs depending on how thick you like your crunchy layer. Also, instead of using any variety of breadcrumbs, look for panko breadcrumbs, which are made from white bread, are delicate, and have almost no flavor.

steps.headline: Lift the fish gently to keep it intact.
steps.description: To achieve the best possible presentation of your fish on the plate, try to hold it together from the moment you buy it until you serve it. Avoid poking the fish with utensils or flipping it during the preparation and baking, as unnecessary and hasty movements will break the fish to pieces. Typically, the fish will already be clean when you purchase it. If not, you can just ask the fishmonger to clean and gut the fish for you.

steps.headline: Coat the fish with fat and season with salt.
steps.description: First, sprinkle the fish with salt and then rub it, inside and out, with a thin film of extra-virgin oil. Extra-virgin oil is the best option for baking fish thanks to its clean taste and health benefits. However, you could use other cooking oils such as sesame oil or butter. Fish has natural fish oils, so you only need to add very little fat for flavor and to prevent the fish from sticking to your baking pan. If you opt for butter, brush a small amount on the fish. Even though salt is essential for flavor, it draws out the moisture and dries out the fish. For a moist and firm fish, add a pinch of salt, but if you want to top up, do so just before you put it in the oven.

steps.headline: Wrap your fish in greased foil.
steps.description: Lay your fish on top of a sheet of foil, which is large enough to wrap the fish. Wrap the foil around the fish by crimping the edges of the foil together. The foil reduces oven and utensil cleaning time, but most importantly it seals the aromas. It also ensures that your fish doesn’t dry out, as the moisture stays within the packet and doesn’t spread into the oven.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: Turn the oven on and set the temperature between 350 °F (177 °C) and 450 °F (232 °C). Depending on how modern your oven is, it should take between 10 to 15 minutes to heat up to the desired temperature. The bigger the fish, the higher the temperature. Increase the oven temperature with the size of your fish.

steps.headline: Line your baking tray with paper or foil.
steps.description: To protect your baking tray from fish's fats and oils, cover it with baking paper or aluminum foil. Place the oven rack in the baking tray. When the fish is ready for baking, put it on the rack. This will reduce the cleaning time, as all the grease will drip into the tray and on the baking paper or foil.

steps.headline: Put the baking tray on the middle shelf of your oven.
steps.description: For baking fish, choose the middle shelf of the oven. At this level the hot air will circulate around the food, resulting in an evenly cooked fish.

steps.headline: Set the oven temperature between 350 °F (177 °C) to 450 °F (232 °C).
steps.description: Depending on the size of your fish, whether it is stuffed or not, and whether it is in foil or not, cooking temperature and cooking time may vary. For example, 35 ounces (0.99 kg) of whole fish, wrapped in foil with light stuffing should cook for about 1 hour in 450 °F (232 °C). Use the conventional heating function of your oven, which you will recognize as the symbol with two lines; one at the top and one at the bottom of a square. This setting distributes heat evenly throughout the oven. The fish can go in the tray horizontally, or if too long, place it diagonally. If you are baking fish fillets and one end is skinnier, fold it to create even thickness, so that all parts are equally cooked.

steps.headline: Check the fish's temperature and texture.
steps.description: The most accurate and quick way to test your fish for doneness is with an instant-read thermometer, which you should stick into the center of the meat and the thickest part. Remove the fish from the oven, if the thermometer shows anything between 120 °F (49 °C) to 145 °F (63 °C), depending on how well-done you prefer your fish. However, if this tool isn’t available in your kitchen, press the fish with your fingertip or a utensil, and if it flakes easily, it is ready. Alternatively, you can use a toothpick to help you check for doneness. Stick the toothpick into the fish’s thickest part, and if the meat is a bit firm and the toothpick comes out clean, your fish is ready. Baked white fish is very delicate and tender, and it can fall apart easily. Don’t turn the fish unless you judge that you absolutely must do so. If you decide to turn the fish, use two spatulas instead of one for more support.

steps.headline: Remove the fish from the oven.
steps.description: The fish will continue to cook for a few minutes after it’s been taken out from the oven. Consider removing the fish just before it’s done, as after it has reached near the desired temperature, this temperature begins to rise quickly with every passing minute. It is therefore in these last minutes that your fish may overcook or dry out.
